title: Real Data Science USA - R Meetup (formerly LA R Users Group): A Decade of Using R in Production  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Real Data Science USA - R Meetup (formerly LA R Users Group)
description:
This is our first (online) event since we moved from California to Texas in July.
We'll fit in a 1-hour slot, talk 35 minutes + Q&A 20 minutes (11:00-11:55am Central Time).
The zoom link will be posted in comments below 5 minutes before the event starts, and due to our zoom's 100-attendee limit, only the first 100 people will be able to join the zoom call. So don't be late.

A Decade of Using R in Production
with Gergely Daroczi, Senior Director of Data Operations at System1

R is often not taken seriously by Real Programmers, and considered a scripting language for ad-hoc data analysis, which is a great interactive tool used by data scientists, but the models (obviously written in notebooks) will eventually need to be productionized using a Real Programming Language. I am also biased, and tend to be similarly opinionated about R (although in the opposite direction), but instead of arguing that R is now ready for production, this talk will just rather share some use-cases and best practices on how I managed to use R in production from small to large companies for ETL, reporting, modeling, live-scoring, stream processing and many more.

Bio: Gergely Daroczi is an enthusiast R user and package developer, Ph.D. in Sociology, former assistant professor, currently working in the industry with 15 years of experience in data science, engineering, cloud infrastructure, and data operations at SaaS, fintech, adtech, and healthtech companies with a strong interest in building scalable data platforms on the top of R and AWS. He maintains a dozen CRAN packages related to using R in production (automated reports, logging, database connections, API integrations), co-authored a number of journal articles in social and medical sciences, and wrote a book on "Mastering Data Analysis with R".

title: SoCal R Users Group (SoCal RUG): Reporting Research Study Results with {gtsummary}  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Abstract:

The {gtsummary} package provides an elegant and flexible way to create publication-ready analytical and summary tables using the R programming language. The {gtsummary} package summarizes data sets, regression models, and more, using sensible defaults with highly customizable capabilities. By leveraging {broom}, {gt}, and {labelled} packages, {gtsummary} creates beautifully formatted, ready-to-share summary and result tables in a single line of R code.

Bio:

Daniel Sjoberg is a Senior Research Biostatistician at Memorial Sloan Kettering, and has collaborated on the planning, analysis, and publication of hundreds of research projects. He is also a doctoral candidate in Biostatistics at Columbia University, where his research focuses on adaptive Bayesian designs in clinical trials. Daniel is the 2021 recipient of the Innovator in Programming and Analysis presented by the American Statistical Association.

title: The Chicago R User Group (CRUG): A Decade of Using R in Production: A CRUG Brunch and Learn Brew and View, United States, US/Canada
description:
R Finance regular, Szilard Pafka, moved from LA to Texas during the pandemic and the LA R User Group went with him. It's now called Real Data Science USA - R Meetup.
https://www.meetup.com/Real-Data-Science-USA-R-Meetup

Their first (online) meetup covers a topic that is near and dear to all of our hearts: R in production! Many of us got the, apparently, well-targeted notification.

The conversation went like this...

Justin Shea (CRUG Organizer):
> https://www.meetup.com/Real-Data-Science-USA-R-Meetup/events/281403393/
Fri 11:10am

CRUG member:
> So… who’s hosting a watch party for the Production R stream?
Fri 4:21pm

Justin Shea
> Idk…haymarket???
Fri 5:49pm

CRUG and Haymarket discussed and (after an embarrassing number of date and time corrections) determined that we could host our very first Brunch and Learn watch party for this event at 11am on 11/11.

*Note: Please do not sign up for the Real Data Science USA event if you plan on attending our event. They have a limited number of online seats!*

**CRUG encourages people to get vaccinated. We are monitoring daily infection and fatality counts (currently falling locally and nationally) and will adjust the parameters of this event based on guidance from the Illinois and Chicago Departments of Public Health.**

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group, United States, US/Canada
description:
Until we can meet again in person, please join our Slack workspace to stay in touch, ask questions, and share information throughout the week.

https://join.slack.com/t/centraliowarusergroup/shared_invite/zt-dhfa5ude-0tvHascxRkn2pgiqDdQgrw

The Slack workspace is available any time, not just Saturday mornings.

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

description:
Join our Webinar: Digitizing Construction with AI on Wednesday,10th November at 6 pm CET to learn how to apply machine learning and artificial intelligence to the 21st century construction site.

About the Talk:

From this talk, you will learn how Scaled Robotics specialists provide highly accurate and precise quality control and progress information on complex construction projects using 3D computer vision, 3D machine learning, and nonlinear optimization. Deep understanding of techniques in 3D to solve complex real-world problems significantly how reality diverges from research.

About the Speaker:

Bharath Sankaran, roboticist by training with expertise in computer vision, machine learning and manipulation, CTO and co-founder of Scaled Robotics.

Register Today through the link: https://bit.ly/x-europe-webinar

title: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjastów R): WhyR? Webinar: Analysing gene variants using Machine Learning, Poland, Europe
group: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjastów R)
description:
WhyR? Webinars are back !

Webinar: https://youtu.be/titHAFO-ias

Title: Analysing gene variants for various clinical characteristics using Machine Learning

Abstract:

In the presentation I’d like to tell a story about recent research we conducted in Invicta R&D. The study was looking to see if it was possible to identify characteristic gene variants for various clinical characteristics of patients undergoing IVF treatment. During the presentation I’m going to discuss in depth the reasons behind our choices of methods, what were the differences between them, what results were expected and what did surprise us. I will share sample of code that was used, bit of theory and a lot of visuals that helped understand the
problem. Don’t worry if you’re not familiar with genetic data – it won’t be necessary to understand
the idea.

Speaker: Krystian Zielinski

Krystian is a Data Scientist in R&D department at Invicta. Previously he worked in financial crime area, where his own-developed tools helped to prevent frauds. Currently he analizes genetic data searching for correlations with medical data. His tools based on AI provide core functionalities in IVF stimulation process. He is also conducting lectures Wyższa Szkoła Bankowa in Gdańsk related to Methods of Machine Learning.

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] Reliable Data Pipelines 101, Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register Here for Free: https://bit.ly/3o7yJwB

Whether it’s for an executive dashboard or an ML model, reliable data is critical for the applications that make data-driven companies tick. But when it comes to creating reliable data pipelines, where do you start and what tools and processes do you need in place?

Egor Gryaznov is the co-founder and CTO of Bigeye and was one of the first data engineers at Uber. Egor will draw from his experience supporting thousands of internal users and mission-critical workloads at Uber to provide an actionable guide to data pipeline reliability.

In this presentation, you will learn:

How to approach building data pipelines for a data application
What tools you will encounter in development and what you need to know about each
How to create SLAs to better align with stakeholders
How to manage the data that your application creates

ABOUT THE SPEAKER

Egor Gryaznov is co-founder and CTO of Bigeye. Prior to co-founding Bigeye, Egor was one of the early engineers at Uber where he scaled the company’s first data warehouse, supporting thousands of internal users and mission-critical workloads. Egor wrote ELT frameworks used by Uber analysts to generate complete data pipelines for KPI reporting from configuration. He developed custom tooling to automate backfills, replication, and critical data warehousing tasks.

Register Here for Free: https://bit.ly/3o7yJwB

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] Machine Teaching: A Gentle Introduction, Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register Here for Free: https://signup.watchful.io/hand-labeling-is-harmful-webinar-0

Subject-matter-expert labeling remains one of the biggest bottlenecks in delivering impactful machine learning applications. Problem owners often lack the necessary engineering and/or data science skills to implement their own model. Machine Teaching workflows enable SME’s to rapidly “teach” models through identifying the most valuable data on which to train on in a dynamic, interactive way.

Shayan Mohanty, CEO of Watchful, joins Hugo Bowne-Anderson, Head of Data Science Evangelism at Coiled, to discuss how machine teaching, a fundamentally transformative approach to human mediate machine intelligence, can be used to tackle your most valuable machine learning use cases. He will give a gentle introduction to the core concepts of Machine Teaching, as well as some examples of how Watchful employs this approach for developing machine learning models.

Register Here for Free: https://signup.watchful.io/hand-labeling-is-harmful-webinar-0

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] When AI Goes Wrong and How to Fix it Fast, Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register here for free: https://info.datascience.salon/when-ai-goes-wrong-and-how-to-fix-it-fast

With algorithms making more and more decisions in our lives, from who gets a job, to who gets hired and fired, and even who goes to jail, it’s more critical than ever to get our intelligent systems talking to us so people can step in when things go wrong.

In the coming decade, organizations will face incredible pressure from regulators and the general public and that means every team needs a plan in place to find and fix mistakes fast or risk PR nightmares and financial disasters.

Join us to learn how to build an AI Red Team to deal with everything from edge cases to outright AI breakdowns, while getting you ready to embrace the latest breakthroughs in explainable AI tomorrow.

Register here for free: https://info.datascience.salon/when-ai-goes-wrong-and-how-to-fix-it-fast

title: Portland R User Group: aggregate: meet, greet, learn, collaborate on Thursday, October 28  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Please join us for the 45th R aggRegate meetup on Zoom! We welcome current or aspiring R users who have any level of experience with the R programming language.

Our goal is to exchange knowledge, learn new skills, help each other troubleshoot coding problems, and meet new fellow R users.

No topic is off limits, and you may attend even if you don’t feel that you have anything to share. Come learn with us!

When: Thursday, Oct 28th, 2021 @ 6:30-8 PM

Where: Online: zoom info provided soon (provided after you join).

Details: David will demonstrate how he and his team developed a website for the API Council highlighting food assets for the Asian Pacific Islander community of San Francisco (https://foodmap.apicouncil.org/). The presentation will highlight the distill package, which was used to create the website. This package makes it easy to create simple websites and get them online — and allows more advanced users to customize the look and feel of websites to match their organizational branding.

Agenda:

• David's demo

• Brief intro/R project or problem: We'll take turns talking about an R project we're working on, a data/data-science problem, or something we want to learn, etc.

• Next, anyone can share some code they've been working on and want help with / want feedback on. Make sure to have this ready before the meeting.

• Before arriving, use the pdxrlang/aggregate GitHub repository to discuss ideas for things to work on at aggregate - https://github.com/pdxrlang/aggregate/issues

Please note that this event, like all PDX R events, adheres to the PDX R Code of Conduct: https://pdxrlang.com/code-of-conduct.html We are dedicated to a safe learning environment to all.

If you have any trouble message Brittany Barker in in the Meetup app, or on Twitter at @pdxrlang

title: Barcelona R User Group: Barcelona R User Group meetup (online)  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Barcelona R User Group - https://www.barcelonar.org/ - is happy to announce the next online meetup event!

See the agenda below (times in Barcelona / CET / UTC +1):

6:15 - 6:30 - Set up (systems check) and virtual hellos
6:30 - 7:30 - Workshop*: Introduction to Machine Learning - by Nicolas Attalides
7:30 - 8:30: Presentations:
1) "Different approaches to Shiny App development" by Andrés Felipe Quintero.
Andrés will talk about different approaches (from a developer point of view) of developing the server logic behind Shiny applications. Many people have different ways of developing server logic and no one way is better than another in all scenarios. Andrés will show off three different ways of writing server logic, how they differ and what downsides and benefits there are to each.
2) "Efficient forecasting considering the Lifecycle stage of a pharmaceutical product" by Eric Matamoros.
Eric is an Expert Data Scientist at Novartis BCN Finance Hub, a hub that has been created with the aim to leverage AI & data-driven decisions to financially assist business through our set of tools. Eric is a curious & passionate data scientist with experience in entrepreneurship and interest in data engineering & modern deep learning.
3) "Becoming an RStudio Super User" by Emil Hvitfeldt
Eric will take you around the myriad of customization and automation available to all RStudio users. This talk will visual customization to custom keybindings to make your workflow smooth and efficient so you can spend all your time focusing on R!

*This workshop covers the basic tasks for building a Machine Learning model in R using {tidymodels}. We learn how to define the problem, design a formula and select an algorithm as well as how to measure the model's performance.
The workshop is designed to be hands-on so if you would like to participate then please join us with your laptop and be ready to code!

See you all soon!

title: R-Ladies Bari: Funnel analyses in R - in partnership con RLadies Coventry  [Virtual] , Italy, Europe
description:
Funnel analyses in R (con il piccolo aiuto di RSQLight)

*** Evento in partnership con R-Ladies Coventry!!! ***

Pubblicato originariamente su RLadies Coventry
https://www.meetup.com/it-IT/rladies-coventry/events/281399088/

Una Funnel Analyses è un metodo di analisi, detto a “imbuto”, utilizzato dalle aziende per comprendere i passaggi che un utente attua per arrivare al risultato voluto dall’azienda. Questo metodo è utilizzato soprattutto per l’analisi del sito web aziendale, in quanto traccia l’esperienza degli utenti sul sito e mostra le fasi che lo portano al raggiungimento di una conversione oppure di un qualche obiettivo per l’azienda, come la registrazione alla newsletter e la generazione di lead.

In questo evento, Sara spiegherà come la Funnel Analyses può aiutare a determinare il punto in cui gli utenti abbandonano la pagina e non completano il percorso che porta alla Conversione. In questo modo l’analisi può essere utilizzata come punto di partenza per capire il motivo per cui gli utenti diminuiscono tra una fase e l’altra e apportare così delle modifiche in grado di ridurre il tasso di uscita e, a sua volta, aumentare il tasso di conversione.
Useremo R-studio per le analisi, creeremo un file R-markdown per produrre un report e riceveremo un piccolo aiuto da un amico - la libreria RSQLite - in modo da poter incorporare il codice SQL nelle nostre analisi e report.

SPEAKER

Questo evento online sarà tenuto dalla (nostra co-fondatrice) dott.ssa Sara Iacozza (https://www.saraiacozza.com/). Sara è attualmente Chief Data Officer e Behavioral Insight Researcher presso Digital Attitudes a Milano. Possiede un dottorato di ricerca presso il Max Planck Institute for Psycholinguistics nei Paesi Bassi.

ENGLISH

Every time you enter a website there are many flows of events that are initiated and can be followed through by a visitor. Imagine you land on the homepage of an e-commerce or a digital academic journal. You are looking for a specific item, that can be a T-shirt or a published paper, and need to navigate through menus and sub-menus before you land on the page you were looking for. What happens most of the time is that only a small portion of visitors achieve their goal of buying the T-shirt or reading the searched paper. Funnel analysis can help you spot where visitors are leaving your website, so you can optimize it and increase conversions.

In this event, Sara will explain how you can analyze funnels to identify key traffic sources and spot significant drop-off points. You’ll also learn how to combine funnel reports with more analytics insight, so you can share strategies that can improve the experience of users. We will use R-studio for the analyses, we’ll create a R-markdown file to output a report, and we will get a little help from a friend - RSQLite library- so that we can embed SQL code in our analyses and report.

SPEAKER
This online event will be led by Dr Sara Iacozza (https://www.saraiacozza.com/). Sara is currently a Chief Data Officer and Behavioural Insight Researcher at Digital Attitudes in Milan, Italy, having previously completed her PhD at the Max Planck Institute for Psycholinguistics in The Netherlands. Sara is a data and R enthusiast who also co-founded R-Ladies Italy!

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct - we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment:
https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

title: CalgaryR: Meta-analysis in Medical Research: A Critical Appraisal and Brief Tutorial  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Please welcome our speaker, Dr. Stephana Julia Moss, PhD Epidemiologist, with the Calgary Critical Care Research Network.

A systematic review and meta-analysis is a scientific exercise that impacts healthcare and health policy. Readers of systematic reviews and meta-analyses may be patients, clinicians, administrators, or policymakers and therefore possess a wide range of skill in understanding research terms. It is important that authors of systematic reviews and meta-analyses make every effort to guide readers in making the best use of results in myriad clinical contexts and settings. Dr. Moss will present a critical appraisal of the methodological approach of a published systematic review and meta-analysis that culminates with a brief tutorial that compares the statistical approach to meta-analysis in STATA and R.

Dr. Moss received her BSc in Biochemistry from the University of Calgary, her MSc in Pharmacology from the University of Alberta, and her PhD in Epidemiology from the University of Calgary. Her most important scholarly contributions to date have centered on how to best partner with citizens in research. Thought leaders and funding agencies have been advocating with limited success for years for researcher-citizen partnerships to maximize the relevance and impact of scholarly work. Dr. Moss’s work epitomizes the value of this conceptual approach.

Please join us and learn together.

title: CalgaryR: R Package DIY  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Please welcome our speaker, Dr. Fonti Kar, Postdoctoral Research Fellow at University of New South Wales, Sydney, Australia.

Do you have a few custom functions on heavy rotation?

Perhaps you have a piece of code that you regularly share with colleagues? Maybe you want to include your analysis code alongside a publication? Why not put it all in an R package?!

This interactive workshop will equip you with the basic skills to create an R package of your own!

Participants should have:

1) a Github account;
2) the most recent version of R and RStudio installed;
3) the following package(s) and their dependencies installed: devtools, testthat, knitr.

Dr. Kar is an evolutionary biologist at heart but is currently working as an R package developer. She works alongside researchers to develop R software tools for the research community. Her interests include biostatistics, reproducible science, learning about the latest coding practices and teaching others to enjoy using R. She is the founder of UNSWcodeRs - a university R user community where students and staff can learn new skills and find coding support.

Please join us and learn together.

title: R-Ladies Bariloche: GRUPO 3. TALLER DE ESTUDIO LIBRO "R PARA CIENCIA DE DATOS"  [Virtual] , Argentina, Latin America
description:
¡Desde RLadies Bariloche les invitamos a comenzar con el estudio en grupo del libro R para Ciencia de Datos (versión traducida al español de R for Data Science) de Hadley Wickham (el creador de Tidyverse y varios paquetes más!). El libro es de libre acceso en https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/ ¡Está muy bueno!

• Nos juntaremos de forma virtual una vez cada 15 días para avanzar con la lectura y comprensión del libro y los scripts. Cada encuentro será guiado por uno o dos integrantes del grupo.

• En el primer encuentro discutiremos el capitulo número 3 “visualización de datos” (¡Qué bueno, empezamos con gráficos con ggplot2 ) https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/visualizaci%C3%B3n-de-datos.html Es necesario llegar a la reunión con el capítulo previamente leído y trabajado. Quienes no leyeron la introducción del libro aún: adelante, es corta, y les dará un panorama de lo que iremos estudiando. En la reunión de organización vimos un panorama de la introducción.

• En base a la encuesta de horarios que hicimos, hemos definido tres grupos de trabajo con distintos horarios. ¡ATENCIÓN! ¡Por favor, anotarse solo en uno de los tres! AHORA ESTÁS EN EL MEETUP DEL GRUPO 3, DE JUEVES DE 18 A 20.

• ¡Importante! Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sólo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies-BRC en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrónico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento.

• Quienes se inscriban al meetup y si aún no se sumaron, van a recibir más adelante un enlace para sumarse al espacio de trabajo de slack que es exclusivo para el estudio del libro y que será nuestra principal vía de comunicación. Si nunca lo usaron y/o necesitan ayuda para familiarizarse, escríbannos y les damos una orientación rápida.

• Necesitamos uno o dos voluntarias o voluntarios para guiar el capítulo número 3. Interesadxs nos lo pueden comunicar por el slack o al correo [masked]. Cuanto antes, mejor. En caso de que nadie se ofrezca, haremos un sorteo (con el comando sample() en R!!!).

• A partir del primer encuentro, cada grupo de trabajo se auto-gestionará. Por ejemplo, sorteará o decidirá quién guiará el siguiente capítulo, si verán un capítulo, medio capítulo o dos capítulos (la propuesta general es ir despacio, lento pero sin tregua), si aplicarán lo que se vió en el capítulo a otro set de datos etc. Contamos con el espacio de slack para consultarnos y compartir información en cada grupo y entre grupos.

Al anotarse, les pedimos que primero lean y acepten el código de conducta que encontrarán en la página.

Para asistir al meetup, les recomendamos poseer una cuenta de google (utilizaremos google meet). Se recomienda tener conocimientos básicos de R.

¡ATENCIÓN! por cuestiones de seguridad virtual, el enlace a la reunión se enviará unos minutos antes de la misma. Por ello les pedimos que
estén alertas al correo.

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: Using R in VS Code  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
VS Code is becoming increasingly popular for many languages, including R, so we have one of the major contributors of its R extension.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack: https://nyhackr.org/slack.html

About the Talk:
As Visual Studio Code was ranked the most popular developer environment in the Stack Overflow 2021 Developer survey, we have been constantly improving R support in VS Code over the past two years. In this talk, I will introduce the powerful code editor specifically for R users and focus on the vscode-R extension, its development and demonstrate its powerful code editing features based on the R language server and flexible interactivity with one or multiple R sessions.

About Kun:
Kun Ren works for a leading hedge fund in China based in Shanghai. He specializes in hedge fund quantitative research framework, architecture, tooling and portfolio optimization. He is a major collaborator of the R extension for Visual Studio Code and R language server, a Microsoft MVP and Author of Learning R Programming, published by Packt Publishing in November 2016.

The talk will begin at 7 PM EDT and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: Fast(ish) Workflows with Billions of Records  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
Long time member of the meetup, and repeat speaker, JD Long returns, virtually, to tell us about big data.

The 2021 Government & Public Sector R Conference will be fully virtual December 8-10. Members of the group can use code nyhackr for a 20% discount at https://rstats.ai/gov/.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack: https://nyhackr.org/slack.html

About the Talk:
Before we even dust off R and start to do analysis, we sometimes have to wrangle ridiculous quantities of data. The promise of cloud vendors is that it is easy with the cloud. The reality is often quite different. Recently, JD was faced with the problem of a recurring workflow that involves joining 35 billion records into a many-to-many join resulting in 75+ billion records and then collapsing that down to summary data. He grabbed a small team of developers and set out on a multi-week journey to figure out how to solve this workflow while minimizing runtime and costs. Some of the most important findings weren't just "which platform to use?" but, more importantly, "how should a team think about this class of problem?" This presentation will be light on R, and heavy on Amazon Web Services but will be of interest to anyone who's wondering what it takes to move billions of rows of data around efficiently.

About JD:
JD Long is co-author of The R Cookbook 2nd Edition and founder of the Chicago R User group. His day job is helping to build risk solutions at a global reinsurance company which involves using a suite of tools that include not only R but also Python, and a host of AWS tooling. JD lived in the NYC area for a number of years and now lives in Richmond, Virginia with his wife, daughter, and dog.

The talk will begin at 7 PM America/New_York and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

title: R-Ladies Buenos Aires: gg+ : paquetes para extender las capacidades de ggplot2  [Virtual] , Argentina, Latin America
description:
Los capítulos de R-Ladies Buenos Aires y R-Ladies Resistencia-Corrientes les traemos el tutorial "gg+ : paquetes para extender las capacidades de ggplot2" a cargo de Luis Verde (@LuisDVerde). Este taller es parte de los tutoriales de LatirR 2021 y se dictará el jueves 4 a las 14hs (hora argentina) GMT-3.

Luis va a mostrarnos distintos paquetes que se suman a ggplot2 para incorporar nuevas paletas de colores, representaciones gráficas y capas (geoms), y herramientas para acomodar y rotular elementos gráficos.

Si sos fan de ggplot2 y querés conocer como extender sus funcionalidades o si estás buscando visualizar datos de forma eficiente y llamativa, ¡este tutorial es para vos!.

Requisitos:
Para aprovechar el tutorial al máximo, instalá previamente los paquetes dplyr, ggalt, ggridges, ggforce, patchwork, ggnewscale, scico, gghighlight, ggrepel, ggeasy, ggfx y ggh4x.

***IMPORTANTE***
Para participar seleccioná "Asistiré" en este evento y asegurate de tener instalado Zoom en tu computadora (https://zoom.us/download).

Por razones de seguridad no compartiremos el link para ingresar a Zoom de manera pública. El mismo día del evento a las 13 hs enviaremos un mail a través de Meetup a todas las personas que confirmaron asistencia con el link para que puedas unirte a la videollamada.

title: Birmingham R User Group (R Programming Language): November BirminghamR Meetup (in-person!), United Kingdom, Europe
group: Birmingham R User Group (R Programming Language)
description:
For the November meetup we're back at the Innovation Campus with our friends Digital Natives. We're looking forward to going to an in-person meetup again and hopefully you are too. There will be 2 talks and food & drinks afterwards.

Agenda

17:30 Pre-meetup Intro to R session
For anyone who wants a short introduction to the R language and community. Also feel free to pose any questions and we'll try our best to help you out.
18:00 Intro to Object Orientated Programming in R - Tom Jemmett
18:30 No more scripts, please! - Adnan Fiaz
19:00 Food and drinks

The location of the meetup is room 0.17 of the Birmingham Innovation Campus (Holt Street, Birmingham B7 4BB).

title: Vienna<-R: TunisR / ViennaR - {colourPicker} & {bs4Dash}  [Virtual] , Austria, Europe
description:
Sharing the third meetup of the TunisR OnePackagePerMeetup series.
This time with a focus on some of the powerful data visualization packages that are available in the programming language R.

TunisR will be hosting Dean Attali and Veerle Van Leemput who will walk through the {colourPicker} and {bs4Dash} Packages in R (meetup link)

➡️ About them:

Dean Attali (https://attalitech.com/) is not a typical R useR - he doesn't know any data science and can't even run a t-test. He has a background in Computer Science and worked in Silicon Valley before falling in love with R. Today Dean is known as The Shiny Guy; he works as a shiny consultant, and if you've done any work with shiny, you probably ran into him. He wrote many popular packages for shiny users, such as {shinyjs}, {timevis}, {shinyalert}, and {colorpicker}, which is what he'll show us today.

Veerle Van Leemput (https://www.linkedin.com/in/veerlevanleemput/) is an entrepreneur and Data Scientist who gets excited about data and programming. She is Managing Director and Head of Data Science at Analytic Health, a UK-based company that develops intelligent and accessible technology which gives organisations the tools they need to accelerate innovation in healthcare. She is an R developer with a Master’s Degree in Data Science and multiple years of experience in the pharmaceutical market. Besides programming in R (and Shiny) she also develops multiple web applications for healthcare organisations using Vue.js and Node at Analytic Health.

➡️ Place: Zoom
➡️ Date/Time: Thursday 11, 2021 from 7PM to 8PM Tunisian time (UTC +1)

We recommend you to have a look at the convenient world clock website https://lnkd.in/gUAZxQM if you're struggling to find the right time according to your time zone.

➡️ Description of the presentations:

➖ You've just made an amazing plot in R, and the only thing remaining is finding the right colours to use. Arghhh this part is never fun... You’re probably familiar with this loop: try some colour values -> plot -> try different colours -> plot -> repeat. Don’t you wish there was a better way?
Well, now there is!
You might find the Plot Colour Helper from the {colourpicker} package handy (https://daattali.com/shiny/colourInput/). It’s an RStudio addin that lets you interactively choose combinations of colours for your plot, while updating your plot in real-time so you can see the colour change. The {colourpicker} package also contains a colour chooser input for shiny apps.

➖ You can make amazing looking R Shiny applications, especially if you use the power of templates. Templates allow you to quickly set up the bare bones of your application and make use of common web elements like headers, sidebars and controlbars. One awesome Shiny template comes from the bs4Dash package (https://rinterface.github.io/bs4Dash/). It lets you use the full power of AdminLTE, a dashboard template built on top of Bootstrap 4. During her presentation, Veerle will show you how to use bs4Dash to make your own Shiny dashboard application. She will go over the main components of the bs4Dash template and she will highlight some cool features like a built-in dark/light mode and pre-loaders. After the presentation you’re all set to leverage the power of bs4Dash yourself in your next Shiny app!

In order to attend the meetup, please fill out this short form
👉 https://tinyurl.com/62y6wp9j

You will get a Zoom link a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.

The first online workshop covered the gganimate R #package by Mitchell O'Hara-Wild. If you have missed the workshop, the recording video is available here: https://youtu.be/uD-H6G-3v10

Looking forward to welcoming you all!

title: R-Ladies Resistencia-Corrientes: gg+ : paquetes para extender las capacidades de ggplot2, Argentina, Latin America
R-Ladies Boulder: RLadies Boulder #20: Reproducible Code & Visualization Best Practices  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description: Welcome back to another edition of RLadies Boulder! This week, Lara Southard, PhD will walk us through Reproducible Code (including the Project Template library) and Visualization Best Practices. Lara is a Sr. Research Scientist at Pearson and has her PhD in Cognitive Neuroscience from CSU.

title: R-Ladies Santiago: Club de lectura del libro "Data Feminism" (sesión 6)  [Virtual] , Chile, Latin America
description:
El próximo jueves 25 de noviembre nos reuniremos para nuestra sexta sesión del club de lectura sobre libro "Data Feminism", de Catherine D'Ignazio y Lauren F. Klein. Este libro muestra una nueva forma de abordar la ciencia de datos y la ética de datos basada en ideas del feminismo interseccional. Se puede acceder de forma gratuita en: https://data-feminism.mitpress.mit.edu/

- ¿Cómo funciona el club de lectura?
Dividiremos la lectura del libro en siete sesiones. En cada una de ellas abordaremos un capítulo del libro.
Esta sexta sesión estará a cargo de Stephanie Orellana (https://twitter.com/sporella). Steph es Ingeniera Agrónoma y Magíster en Recursos Naturales de la PUC, y trabaja en consultoría ambiental. Su área de especialización es la Ciencia de Datos Espaciales. Durante la sesión comentaremos el capítulo 6, "The Numbers Don't Speak for Themselves", en el que se presenta el sexto principio del feminismo de datos: considerar el contexto.

- ¿Qué pasa si no puedo leer en inglés?
¡Puedes participar igual! La persona encargada de cada sesión hará una síntesis de los puntos más importantes, así que incluso si no puedes revisar el libro, podrás aprender sobre este tema :)

- CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA
Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish
El evento se realizará a través de la plataforma Zoom. El día del taller compartiremos la contraseña en los comentarios del evento.

- HORA
El evento se realizará a las 18:00 horas de la zona horaria UTC-3. Puedes revisar a qué hora corresponde en tu zona en el siguiente enlace: https://everytimezone.com/s/2137585e/

title: R-Ladies Philly: Getting Started with Unit Testing in R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
In this workshop, we’ll discuss how to get started with unit testing in R, which is formal automated testing of functions within packages. We’ll demonstrate handy functions in `usethis` and `devtools`, strategies for writing tests, debugging techniques, and broad concepts in function writing that facilitate a smoother testing process.

This workshop will pick up exactly where we left our little `ralph` (aka R-Ladies Philly) package one year ago with “Your first R package in 1 hour: Tools that make R package development easy” (https://www.pipinghotdata.com/talks/2020-10-25-your-first-r-package-in-1-hour/). Participants will get the most out of this workshop if they review those materials in advance, or if they are already familiar with building R packages with `devtools` and `usethis`.

Materials for the workshop are available here: https://github.com/shannonpileggi/ralphGetsTested

After a long summer break we are happy to announce the November 2021 Meetup with Maëlle Salmon (https://masalmon.eu) who will give us a presentation on best practices to organize an R project and why R projects are important.

Here is Maëlle's abstract for the talk:
"A good R project organization is useful even if you do not have
collaborators as demanding as The Little Prince. how to do that? Do you put the project in some sort of box? In this talk I will present tools that are good to know: git, here, renv, targets, orderly… I’ll also report whether making an R package out of everything is always a good idea. After this presentation you will have learnt tips and tricks to apply as you like in your R projects. I hope every one of you will learn at least one new thing!"

Maëlle is a part-time research software engineer for rOpenSci (since February 2018) and an active R developer and trainer. She also serve as associate editor for rOpenSci’s Software Peer Review (peer-review system of R packages) and is the main manager of R-Ladies Global Twitter account.

title: trigeR - Trójmiejska Grupa Entuzjastów R: WhyR? Webinar: Analysing gene variants using Machine Learning  [Virtual] , Poland, Europe

WhyR? Webinars are back !

Webinar: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=titHAFO-ias

Title: Analysing gene variants for various clinical characteristics using Machine Learning

Abstract:

In the presentation I’d like to tell a story about recent research we conducted in Invicta R&D. The study was looking to see if it was possible to identify characteristic gene variants for various clinical characteristics of patients undergoing IVF treatment. During the presentation I’m going to discuss in depth the reasons behind our choices of methods, what were the differences between them, what results were expected and what did surprise us. I will share sample of code that was used, bit of theory and a lot of visuals that helped understand the
problem. Don’t worry if you’re not familiar with genetic data – it won’t be necessary to understand
the idea.

Speaker: Krystian Zielinski

Krystian is a Data Scientist in R&D department at Invicta. Previously he worked in financial crime area, where his own-developed tools helped to prevent frauds. Currently he analizes genetic data searching for correlations with medical data. His tools based on AI provide core functionalities in IVF stimulation process. He is also conducting lectures Wyższa Szkoła Bankowa in Gdańsk related to Methods of Machine Learning.

description:
Know the basics of data wrangling but want some hands-on practice? Want to learn ggplot tips and tricks to make your plots eye-catching? Seen cool visualizations on Twitter but find it hard to go from messy dataset to beautiful visualization?

In this monthly meetup, we’ll go through a Tidy Tuesday dataset together step-by-step, walking you through the entire process from coming up with an interesting question to asnwer, getting the data in the right format and finally, creating a cool visualization!

You may have heard of Tidy Tuesday -- a weekly initiative by R for Data Science which provides a new dataset every week for the community to practice wrangling and visualizing. It has a huge Twitter community and is one of the best ways to practice and develop tidyverse skills, whether you’re still reviewing the basics or have quite the repertoire. This series has something for everyone and is especially designed to be beginner friendly!

It's important to us to ensure that Guided Tidy Tuesday is a safe space for gender minorities and especially those who are just starting out with R. Este libro muestra una nueva forma de abordar la ciencia de datos y la ética de datos basada en ideas del feminismo interseccional. Se puede acceder de forma gratuita en: https://data-feminism.mitpress.mit.edu/

- ¿Cómo funciona el club de lectura?
Dividiremos la lectura del libro en siete sesiones. En cada una de ellas abordaremos un capítulo del libro.
Esta sexta sesión estará a cargo de Stephanie Orellana (https://twitter.com/sporella). Steph es Ingeniera Agrónoma y Magíster en Recursos Naturales de la PUC y trabaja en consultoría ambiental. Su área de especialización es la Ciencia de Datos Espaciales.. Durante la sesión comentaremos el capítulo 6, "The Numbers Don't Speak for Themselves", en el que se presenta el sexto principio del feminismo de datos: considerar el contexto.

- ¿Qué pasa si no puedo leer en inglés?
¡Puedes participar igual! La persona encargada de cada sesión hará una síntesis de los puntos más importantes, así que incluso si no puedes revisar el libro, podrás aprender sobre este tema :)

title: BernR: Anonymizing data using Statistical Disclosure Control  [Virtual] , Switzerland, Europe
description:
A presentation by Dr. Matthias Templ from the ZHAW School of Engineering.

The event takes place online. The link to the meeting will be visible for registered participants shortly before the beginning of the event (at the latest).

----

New technologies and research in the field of machine learning and deep learning methods and new ways of accessing, integrating and analyzing sensitive personal data increase the demand for solutions to be able to respect laws on data privacy and confidentiality. Fields of applications include official statistics and social sciences, financial transactions, social network activities, location trajectories, CRM, insurance data and medical records.
New data protection regulations, that especially include high penalties for violating privacy, put the topic of statistical disclosure control in focus.

There are a lot of different concepts to consider data privacy. To name a few: privacy preserving computation, remote execution, remote access, synthetic data, and statistical disclosure control. We focus on the latter one. Statistical disclosure control includes the measurement of the re-identification risk of persons in a data set, the anonymization of data and the measurement of the information loss after anonymization. After anonymization the data include no link to persons, and thus all the rules on privacy do no longer apply.

Based on an application using the European Survey of Income and Living Condition, we show the S4 class R package sdcMicro in action. Note, that each anonymization should be done very data- and use-case specific, and an anonymization of different kinds of data (e.g. mobility data, event history data, time series, longitudinal data) needs different solutions.

The audience is expected to have knowledge in base R.

Further readings, resources and documents:

Publications (selection):
- Journal of Statistical Software: sdcMicro
https://www.jstatsoft.org/article/view/v067i04
- Publication about sdc app
https://www.mdpi.com/1999-4893/12/9/191/htm
- Online test version
https://sdctools.shinyapps.io/sdcapp/
- Book on SDC in Springer
https://www.springer.com/de/book/9783319502700

Resources:
- sdcMicro development on github
https://github.com/sdcTools/sdcMicro
- sdcMicro stable CRAN version
https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/sdcMicro/index.html

See also:
- International Household Survey Network
http://www.ihsn.org/software/disclosure-control-toolbox
- World Bank Group
http://surveys.worldbank.org/sdcmicro

title: EdinbR: The Edinburgh R Usergroup: November 2021: DecaRbonisation and climate target modelling  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
description:
Hi everyone,
<br/>

Our third session of 2021/22 is our second focused on **climate** and will be on November 17th, join us from 5.30pm online! As usual, the meeting is open for all to attend, and newcomers / beginners are especially welcome.

We're using a chat group for EdinbR, come and catch up with the community on Matrix (https://matrix.to/#/#edinbr:matrix.org).
Our talk this month will primarily be available on Matrix - along with session chat. We will also be running a stream to YouTube, if you are unable to join us on Matrix.

Our speakers are Iris Oren and Robin Lovelace.

* **Iris Oren** is an Operational Research Analyst in the Energy and Climate Change Analysis team of Scottish Government. She uses R in modelling work and tries to promote the use of open source tools for reproducible analysis in government.

* **Robin Lovelace** is an Associate Professor of Transport Data Science at the Leeds Institute for Transport Studies (ITS) with research interests ranging from optimal zoning systems for urban analysis to analysis of road safety data. He is also a keen R user, developer and teacher, author of Geocomputation with R (https://geocompr.robinlovelace.net/) and several R packages.

---

## R package for climate target modelling (TIMES)

### Iris Oren

What is the optimal way for a country to meet its climate change targets taking into account the myriad of complex constraints that exist? The TIMES modelling framework (https://iea-etsap.org/index.php/etsap-tools/model-generators/times) is used internationally to model energy systems and answer this question. To date, TIMES has largely been used by means of a graphical user interface. I will present a new R package that enables TIMES data to be imported and analysed in R, enhancing the reproducibility of energy systems modelling.

---

## Open source software for decaRbonisation

### A case study of tools to support sustainable transport plans

### Robin Lovelace (https://www.robinlovelace.net/)

Robin will discuss his experience of researching and deploying transport models to inform sustainable policies. R underpins his role as Lead Developer of the Propensity to Cycle Tool (https://www.pct.bike/), an open source and open access tool being used to support evidence-based strategic cycle network plans.

---

See you there!

/federico

title: R-Ladies RTP: Filling in the Blanks: Multiply Imputing Missing Data in R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
This event will explore the topics around missing data and how to deal with them in your analysis. A short introduction will be given, providing an overview of the different types of missing data, ways to account for them, and which of these ways are preferred (and why). We will demonstrate the multiple imputation approach in R and allow time for the participants to practice on real data.

A big big thanks to R-Ladies RTP members, Marissa Ashner and Dr. Sarah Lotspeich, for volunteering their time to organize and lead this event!

Agenda:
6:30 pm - 6:45pm - Introductions
6:45 pm - 7:15 pm - Overview of Missing Data
7:15 pm - 8:15 pm - Examples and practice in R
8:15 pm - 8:30 pm - Wrap up

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them (i.e., attend through the "guest" function on their host's RSVP, not as a separate RSVP). This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please contact the event organizer.

Who is this for?
This meetup is for beginners who have little to no experience programming in R. We will use live coding demonstrations and participates will actively engage with the instructor throughout the workshop.

**Before you join**, please install the most recent version of R **as well as** RStudio on your computer before attending this meetup event. Here are links to free downloads for R (https://cran.r-project.org/) and RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/#download). Downloading and installing both of these programs before this meetup will help us keep to our schedule and make sure you learn the most you can while at the meetup event.

If you have trouble installing the software, please contact Sheila (via Meetup message or at [masked]) at least 48 hours **before the event** so we can find a time to meet and work through software installation issues.

What should I bring?
Please login to Zoom using a laptop or computer with the capabilities to run R **and** RStudio. See information above about how to install R **and** RStudio.

Where will it take place?
Please join us online via Zoom. A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please contact the event organizer.

title: Köln R User Group: R User Group Meeting  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
We're looking for speakers again! Please reach out if you would like to prepare a talk.

Agenda:

## TALK 1 Finding Topics in Text Data using NLP and Neural Networks

Speaker: Dr. Daniel Bendel

This talk is about how to analyze free text with R and Python. We collected over 7,000 open text explanations from our users on why they opted out of one of our main features. Of course, I couldn't read every answer and classify it manually, therefore I needed to use a variety of tools to make sense out of these answers and group them in informative clusters, which I would like to present today.

## TALK 2 The gt Package: Introduction and Demo

Speaker: Richard Iannone

The gt package is table preparation package for R which makes the presentation of tabular data fairly easy. The package allows for a lot of customization. We can format cell values, apply footnotes, styles cells, and much more.

I'll provide some background on gt and show you what it is capable of doing today. There will be a demo of gt in the RStudio IDE and we’ll work through a number of examples of what kinds of tables can be made.

## Social Gathering

After the talks we want you to virtually meet, chat, network, and discuss interesting topics.

title: R-Ladies Milan: Funnel analysis in R - in partnership con RLadies Coventry  [Virtual] , Italy, Europe
description:
Funnel analyses in R (con il piccolo aiuto di RSQLight)

*** Evento in partnership con R-Ladies Coventry!!! ***

Pubblicato originariamente su RLadies Coventry
https://www.meetup.com/it-IT/rladies-coventry/events/281399088/

Una Funnel Analyses è un metodo di analisi, detto a “imbuto”, utilizzato dalle aziende per comprendere i passaggi che un utente attua per arrivare al risultato voluto dall’azienda. Questo metodo è utilizzato soprattutto per l’analisi del sito web aziendale, in quanto traccia l’esperienza degli utenti sul sito e mostra le fasi che lo portano al raggiungimento di una conversione oppure di un qualche obiettivo per l’azienda, come la registrazione alla newsletter e la generazione di lead.

In questo evento, Sara spiegherà come la Funnel Analyses può aiutare a determinare il punto in cui gli utenti abbandonano la pagina e non completano il percorso che porta alla Conversione. In questo modo l’analisi può essere utilizzata come punto di partenza per capire il motivo per cui gli utenti diminuiscono tra una fase e l’altra e apportare così delle modifiche in grado di ridurre il tasso di uscita e, a sua volta, aumentare il tasso di conversione.
Useremo R-studio per le analisi, creeremo un file R-markdown per produrre un report e riceveremo un piccolo aiuto da un amico - la libreria RSQLite - in modo da poter incorporare il codice SQL nelle nostre analisi e report.

SPEAKER

Questo evento online sarà tenuto dalla (nostra co-fondatrice) dott.ssa Sara Iacozza (https://www.saraiacozza.com/). Sara è attualmente Chief Data Officer e Behavioral Insight Researcher presso Digital Attitudes a Milano. Possiede un dottorato di ricerca presso il Max Planck Institute for Psycholinguistics nei Paesi Bassi.

ENGLISH

Every time you enter a website there are many flows of events that are initiated and can be followed through by a visitor. Imagine you land on the homepage of an e-commerce or a digital academic journal. You are looking for a specific item, that can be a T-shirt or a published paper, and need to navigate through menus and sub-menus before you land on the page you were looking for. What happens most of the time is that only a small portion of visitors achieve their goal of buying the T-shirt or reading the searched paper. Funnel analysis can help you spot where visitors are leaving your website, so you can optimize it and increase conversions.

In this event, Sara will explain how you can analyze funnels to identify key traffic sources and spot significant drop-off points. You’ll also learn how to combine funnel reports with more analytics insight, so you can share strategies that can improve the experience of users. We will use R-studio for the analyses, we’ll create a R-markdown file to output a report, and we will get a little help from a friend - RSQLite library- so that we can embed SQL code in our analyses and report.

SPEAKER
This online event will be led by Dr Sara Iacozza (https://www.saraiacozza.com/). Sara is currently a Chief Data Officer and Behavioural Insight Researcher at Digital Attitudes in Milan, Italy, having previously completed her PhD at the Max Planck Institute for Psycholinguistics in The Netherlands. Sara is a data and R enthusiast who also co-founded R-Ladies Italy!

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct - we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment:
https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

title: R-Ladies New York: R-Wars: Tidyverse vs. Base R and Writing Reports in R Markdown  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For our November event, we will have two guest speakers. Dorota Biedzio will discuss the advantages and disadvantages between the tidyverse and base R. Alyssa Goldberg will teach us how to batch-process reports using RMarkdown.

This event will be hosted over Zoom, and the link will be available on this Meetup page at noon on the day of the event.

Agenda (times approximate):
7:05pm - 7:10pm: R-Ladies NYC Announcements
7:10pm - 7:40pm: Dorota's talk on tidyverse vs. base R
7:40pm - 8:10pm: Alyssa's talk on using R Markdown to write reports

--- Talk Abstract ---

"Tidyverse vs. Base R"
Speaker: Dorota Biedzio

Abstract: The rivalry between base-R and the tidyverse ends now! We will discuss the pros and cons of each, and compare code snippets to finally choose a winner! Or... instead... we can have an intellectual, even-tempered discussion because we are all professionals.

Bio: Dorota is a masters-level statistician currently working as a data analyst at MDRC (a non-profit, non-partisan research organization). Dorota loves writing functions that can automate tedious data processing tasks and increase workflow efficiency.

"Batch Processing R Markdown Reports"
Speaker: Alyssa Goldberg

Abstract: I'll be showing folks how to use R and RMarkdown to batch generate several reports at once - sort of like facet_wrap() but for
Word documents.

Bio: Alyssa is the Senior Marketing Analyst at the law firm Debevoise & Plimpton LLP.

title: R-Ladies Concepción: Club de Lectura del libro "Data Feminism" (Sesión 6).   [Virtual] , Chile, Latin America
description:
El próximo jueves 25 de noviembre nos reuniremos para nuestra sexta sesión del club de lectura sobre libro "Data Feminism", de Catherine D'Ignazio y Lauren F. Klein. Este libro muestra una nueva forma de abordar la ciencia de datos y la ética de datos basada en ideas del feminismo interseccional. Se puede acceder de forma gratuita en: https://data-feminism.mitpress.mit.edu/

- ¿Cómo funciona el club de lectura?
Dividiremos la lectura del libro en siete sesiones. En cada una de ellas abordaremos un capítulo del libro.
Esta sexta sesión estará a cargo de Stephanie Orellana (https://twitter.com/sporella). Steph es Ingeniera Agrónoma y Magíster en Recursos Naturales de la PUC, y trabaja en consultoría ambiental. Su área de especialización es la Ciencia de Datos Espaciales. Durante la sesión comentaremos el capítulo 6, "The Numbers Don't Speak for Themselves", en el que se presenta el sexto principio del feminismo de datos: considerar el contexto.

- ¿Qué pasa si no puedo leer en inglés?
¡Puedes participar igual! La persona encargada de cada sesión hará una síntesis de los puntos más importantes, así que incluso si no puedes revisar el libro, podrás aprender sobre este tema :)

- CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA
Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish
El evento se realizará a través de la plataforma Zoom. El día del taller compartiremos la contraseña en los comentarios del evento.

- HORA
El evento se realizará a las 18:00 horas de la zona horaria UTC-3. Puedes revisar a qué hora corresponde en tu zona en el siguiente enlace:

https://everytimezone.com/s/2137585e/

title: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup: November Meet-up, United Kingdom, Europe
group: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup
description:
Newcastle's premier Data Science event is back, and we're in person!

The event space will be accessible from 1730h and until 2030h for any who wish to arrive prior to the session starting, or remain after finishing.

---
Schedule
1800--1830h: Refreshments
1830--1900h: Jack Kennedy, Newcastle University
1915--2000h: Laura Cole, National Audit Office
---

---
Jack Kennedy, Newcastle University

Title
Making costly decisions with complex computer models

Abstract
In industry and government, decision makers are assisted by analysts when making complex decisions. In many cases, complex computer models allow analysts to explore future scenarios to advise the decision maker on appropriate policies to make. This task is often reduced to one of mathematical optimisation under uncertainty; the best policy to take is the one which maximises the expected returns.

The decision making task is often difficult because (a) the computer models used take long time periods to run; (b) the models may be stochastic (exhibit random properties) and (c) these models are merely approximations to reality.

I'll present an approach to dealing with these challenges in the context of maximising the performance of an offshore wind farm.
---

---
Laura Cole, National Audit Office

Title
Everything you ever wanted to know about Financial Modelling at the National Audit Office but were afraid to ask

Abstract
The National Audit Office (NAO) is responsible for auditing £1.7tr [masked]) of government spending; we audit the financial statements of all central government departments, agencies and other public bodies, and report the results to Parliament. We are also responsible for assessing the value that this spending achieves. Using our special access rights to request almost any data from government, we produce a range of outputs, across a vast range of topics. One of these outputs is auditing financial models that underpin government spending projections.

In this short presentation I will explain:

What the objectives of the Modelling team are and how we collaborate with internal and external stakeholders;
How we use internally collected data to decide on our model assurance approach and how we visualise this data in an RShiny app; and
How analysts are involved in quality assuring outputs generated from government models.

Biography
In 2016 Laura graduated from Newcastle University with a PhD in Applied Mathematics, with research focusing on the Solar Dynamo. She took up a role in the Civil Service Fast Stream and worked as a statistician at the DWP and then an executive agency of HMRC. In 2019, she joined the NAO as a Senior Analyst and has lead on the Modelling team’s Data Science strategy, as well as delivering model assurance (and managing/mentoring others to deliver model assurance) on over 50 business critical models that feed into government accounts. This week marks the beginning of the next step in her career after securing promotion to Head of Modelling at the NAO. Outside of work, she enjoys participating in programming challenges (e.g. Project Euler, Tidy Tuesday) and enjoys spending time with her young family, including her cockerpoo Bailey.
---

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group, United States, US/Canada
description:
Until we can meet again in person, please join our Slack workspace to stay in touch, ask questions, and share information throughout the week.

https://join.slack.com/t/centraliowarusergroup/shared_invite/zt-dhfa5ude-0tvHascxRkn2pgiqDdQgrw

The Slack workspace is available any time, not just Saturday mornings.

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjastów R): Why R? Webinar: Recent developments of Joint Models using R, Poland, Europe
group: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjastów R)
description:
WhyR? Webinars are back !

Webinar: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eC1-B2RLGwk

Title:
Recent developments of Joint Models for longitudinal and survival data using R

Abstract:

Many biomedical follow-up studies aim to investigate the relationship between a repeated measurement, measured with error and time-to-event data. Joint modelling approaches are used to study these two types of data simultaneously to assess the effect of longitudinal biomarkers on time-to-event data. The first joint modelling proposals have been based on a relationship between one single longitudinal biomarker and time-to-event data. Recently, several extensions have been developed for multivariate longitudinal and survival data, for non-linear longitudinal and survival data, to use different association structures between the longitudinal biomarker and patients` survival and for personalized dynamic predictions of time-to-event data. In this talk, we will focus on the recent developments of joint models from both frequentist and Bayesian perspective, with developed R packages.

Speaker: Ipek Guler

I am Ipek Guler born in Turkey in 1986, after finishing my University degree in Gazi University, Ankara, I have started to my master degree in University of Santiago de Compostela, Spain where I have specialized in applied statistical techniques. During my master studies, I had different internships in Clinical Hospital of Santiago de Compostela, IDICHUS and a spin-off company and I focused my research on longitudinal and survival data.

I have worked in several research projects as a researcher in biostatistics group of University of Santiago de Compostela during 6 years, as a statistical consultant in Maimonides Biomedical Research Institute of Córdoba (IMIBIC) for 2 years and also have worked in national Covid registry data with the Spanish Internal Medicine Society (SEMI). I am currently working in Leuven Biostatistics and Statistical Bioinformatics Centre (L-BioStat) KU Leuven.

description:
** Please ALSO register here to secure your spot **
https://gotopia.tech/events/94/sign_up

--
Speaker: Rasmus Bååth
Date: December 14, 2021
Time: 5.30pm - 6.45pm
Location: Trifork, Borgergade 24B, 1300 Copenhagen

AGENDA

5:30pm - Doors open
5:45pm - Welcome by GOTO
5:50pm - Three Strategies to Tackle Big Data in R with Rasmus Bååth
6:30pm - Q&A
6:45pm - Thank you for today

ABSTRACT

Big data might not be the buzzword it was five years ago, but it's more prevalent than ever. Even if you aren't currently dealing with big data, chances are that sooner or later you'll find yourself with a dataset that is just too big for your normal R setup to handle.

At this meetup in collaboration with CopenhagenR, Rasmus Bååth, data science lead at Castle.io, will share three strategies that can be used to tackle big data in R (and python if that's your cup of tea). Three big data tools will be briefly introduced: duckDB, Spark and SnowflakeDB.

The CopenhagenR meetup is ramping up again and invites you to join this event aimed at everybody working with or interested in data science.

ABOUT THE SPEAKERS

Rasmus Bååth - Rasmus is a data science lead at Castle.io, a Y combinator-backed startup building an AI-based security and fraud detection service. He's worked with big data in many different forms and knows that, while it can be a pain to handle big data, there can be great business value (and good career opportunities) knowing how to do so.

title: Cleveland R User Group: Andres Rodriguez: Gravity Model of European Soccer Player Transfers  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Gravity Model of European Soccer Player Transfers

Newton's law of universal gravitation was stated in the 17th century as "every particle attracts every other particle in the universe with a force that is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the distance between their centers." This law was then the inspiration of Jan Tinbergen's work on Econometric Gravity Models of International Trade in the 20th century.

I will demonstrate how the work of Newton and Tinbergen inspired me to create a model of Soccer Player Transfers in European Soccer using:

* rvest to web scrape
* ggmap and Google Cloud Platform to geocode addresses
* geosphere to calculate latitude and longitude distance

Hope to see you there.

Andres Rodriguez has been an avid R User for 5 years now and currently works as a Data Analyst in Progressive Insurance's Commercial Lines division. He is passionate about using R to create soccer data analyses which can be seen at his blog socceranalyticsfc.com

Note: this talk will be recorded and posted on our YouTube channel.

title: Wellington R Users Group (WRUG): Masterclass: R for data visualisation (and reporting)  [Virtual] , New Zealand, Australia
description:
Whether you are a beginner or are needing a refresh, you can join this training to gain familiarity with the statistical programming language R and learn how to take your data and reporting to the next level.

We have developed this intro level training to give people a leg up to get started toward reporting and dashboards in R - we would appreciate if you could share with potentially interested colleagues outside of the group. Hope to see some of you there, too!

ABOUT THIS EVENT:
Have you got lots of ideas of what you want to do with your data but just can’t get there yet? Over 5 sessions we will look into the basics of the statistical programming language R and how it can be applied to data visualisation and automated report generation. We cover data cleaning and pre-processing, transforming your data, displaying it in multiple formats (data table and plots), and finally tying it all together in a R Markdown file that you can save and share with your audience. We will work through multiple datasets and exercises so on conclusion of the class you can hit the ground running.

WHO SHOULD ATTEND:
You are new to R or feel a bit rusty with your R skills and have a keen interest in furthering your ability to manage, display and share data. Maybe you have been mainly using Excel or an off-the shelf tool like Power BI, but are frustrated by its limitations and are keen to build more advanced visuals to do your data justice. You might have a dataset or model you want to prepare outputs for and want to progress to a more powerful, efficient and streamlined process. This Masterclass can be used as an entry into R or can be used as preparation for our R Shiny Masterclasses.

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: Pins - where have you been all my life?  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our December Meetup (last of 2021!) will be a remote gathering; the Zoom link will be posted the week of the event.

Like that one piece of furniture in your living room that you need, but you just can’t find a spot for, we often struggle to find a home for the mid‐process artifacts of a data analysis.
Think about some of your workflows. Are you:
• Using read_csv() to bring in emailed data?
• Saving .Rds or .RData objects to be called later?
• Sharing your model or data across multiple apps?
• Redeploying your app every time the supporting data is updated?
A “yes” to any of the above indicates a solid use case for pins. Pins were developed to make discovering, caching, and sharing resources simpler. Learn how to get started with this gem of a package and how it can help promote more efficient workflows.

Katie Masiello got her start in R doing statistical and risk analysis in the aerospace industry. Since joining RStudio in 2019, she has worked with RStudio’s enterprise customers to demonstrate and build value in their analytics using RStudio’s suite of professional and open source tools. She works with teams across a full spectrum - those just beginning their journey with data science to those fully entrenched in high-value production deployments - to share best practices, teach more efficient workflows, and empower teams to shine.

title: Saint Louis R User Group: KNIME Workflows for Citizen Data Science  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
By: Jay Harrison

KNIME is a free, open-source platform for data science. KNIME users construct workflows by joining nodes, or icons representing specific functions, in a logical sequence. This low-code approach is attractive for people who want perform data analysis tasks without learning a programming language. KNIME is not a comprehensive solution, but R code can be incorporated and executed to fill in the gaps. We will demonstrate KNIME and describe its use in a citizen data scientist program.

Scott Fincher and Cynthia Padilla from KNIME will also be joining us. They will answer the technical and business-related questions that people may have.

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by Tunis R: Exploration of Tidy Network Data Using {tidygraph} in R  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

Please note: In order to attend the meetup, please fill out this short form 👉 https://tinyurl.com/4srp7y66
by Thursday, December 2,[masked] PM

----------------------------------------------

We are happy to announce the fourth meetup of the OnePackagePerMeetup new series that we have recently started at Tunis R User Group. We will have the great pleasure to be monthly hosting amazing guests! For the next few months we will focus on some of the powerful data visualization packages that are available in the programming language R.

We are delighted to be hosting Thomas Lin Pedersen who will walk through the tidygraph package in R (https://www.data-imaginist.com/2017/introducing-tidygraph/). Thomas Lin Pedersen is a software engineer at RStudio focusing on developing and maintaining the various packages that makes data visualisation possible in R. He is the maintainer of ggplot2 and the developer of a range of extensions such as patchwork, ggforce, and gganimate. In the spare time, Thomas makes generative art created with R using the same tools as he develops for data visualisation.

➡️ Place: Zoom
➡️ Date/Time: December 2, 2021 from 7PM to 9PM Tunisian time (UTC +1)

We recommend you to have a look at the convenient world clock website https://lnkd.in/gUAZxQM if you're struggling to find the right time according to your time zone.

➡️ About the workshop:
Working with network data can be daunting for people used to the more classic tabular data types. The packages tidygraph and ggraph have been developed to bring some of the familiarity of dplyr and ggplot2 to working with network data with the hope that more people will be comfortable wrangling and analysing this type of data. This workshop will introduce the core concepts of network data and show how it can be tamed with the help of tidygraph and ggraph.

In order to attend the meetup, please fill out this short form 👉 https://tinyurl.com/4srp7y66

group: Warwick R User Group (R Programming Language)
description:
The Advent of Code (https://adventofcode.com), a series of daily programming puzzles running up to Christmas, starts soon. On 3 December, the Manchester R-thritis Statistical Computing Group, jointly with Warwick R User Group, is hosting an informal online meetup where we will discuss different approaches to tackling (and hopefully solving) the challenges using R and related languages/tools.
