title: CalgaryR: Introduction to Shiny App in R  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Please welcome our speaker, David Aponte, PhD Candidate in medical science at the University of Calgary.

Shiny is an R framework for interacting with data through a web app. If you have complex data that is either continuously updated or big enough for people to explore for their own insights, Shiny is a fantastic library for creating visual tools to open up your data to the broader community. Shiny apps can easily be deployed to the web, allowing others to leverage your data and analyses without the fuss of installing anything or writing code.

In this workshop, we will learn the basics of making a Shiny application, starting with how you can take your existing analyses and make them work with user selectable inputs. We’ll also go over some tips for making your Shiny app work efficiently and look slick. Finally, we will go over deploying your Shiny application to a live website for anyone to use.

If you’d like to follow along with the workshop, make sure to download the Github repository from https://github.com/J0vid/CalgaryR_Shiny. The GitHub readme briefly outlines the goals of the workshop, as well as potential future topics.

About the speaker:

David Aponte is a PhD Candidate in medical science at the University of Calgary. His dissertation work has focused on how genetic variation produces facial shape variation in mice and humans. He has used R for a wide array of projects like measuring color patterns from image data and identifying genetic syndromes from measurements of facial shape.

Please join us and learn together.

title: R-Ladies Bariloche: GRUPO 3. TALLER DE ESTUDIO LIBRO "R PARA CIENCIA DE DATOS"  [Virtual] , Argentina, Latin America
description:
¡Desde RLadies Bariloche les invitamos a comenzar con el estudio en grupo del libro R para Ciencia de Datos (versión traducida al español de R for Data Science) de Hadley Wickham (el creador de Tidyverse y varios paquetes más!). El libro es de libre acceso en https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/ ¡Está muy bueno!

• Nos juntaremos de forma virtual una vez cada 15 días para avanzar con la lectura y comprensión del libro y los scripts. Cada encuentro será guiado por uno o dos integrantes del grupo.

• En el primer encuentro discutiremos el capitulo número 3 “visualización de datos” (¡Qué bueno, empezamos con gráficos con ggplot2 ) https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/visualizaci%C3%B3n-de-datos.html Es necesario llegar a la reunión con el capítulo previamente leído y trabajado. Quienes no leyeron la introducción del libro aún: adelante, es corta, y les dará un panorama de lo que iremos estudiando. En la reunión de organización vimos un panorama de la introducción.

• En base a la encuesta de horarios que hicimos, hemos definido tres grupos de trabajo con distintos horarios. ¡ATENCIÓN! ¡Por favor, anotarse solo en uno de los tres! AHORA ESTÁS EN EL MEETUP DEL GRUPO 3, DE JUEVES DE 18 A 20.

• ¡Importante! Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sólo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies-BRC en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrónico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento.

• Quienes se inscriban al meetup y si aún no se sumaron, van a recibir más adelante un enlace para sumarse al espacio de trabajo de slack que es exclusivo para el estudio del libro y que será nuestra principal vía de comunicación. Si nunca lo usaron y/o necesitan ayuda para familiarizarse, escríbannos y les damos una orientación rápida.

• Necesitamos uno o dos voluntarias o voluntarios para guiar el capítulo número 3. Interesadxs nos lo pueden comunicar por el slack o al correo [masked]. Cuanto antes, mejor. En caso de que nadie se ofrezca, haremos un sorteo (con el comando sample() en R!!!).

• A partir del primer encuentro, cada grupo de trabajo se auto-gestionará. Por ejemplo, sorteará o decidirá quién guiará el siguiente capítulo, si verán un capítulo, medio capítulo o dos capítulos (la propuesta general es ir despacio, lento pero sin tregua), si aplicarán lo que se vió en el capítulo a otro set de datos etc. Contamos con el espacio de slack para consultarnos y compartir información en cada grupo y entre grupos.

Al anotarse, les pedimos que primero lean y acepten el código de conducta que encontrarán en la página.

Para asistir al meetup, les recomendamos poseer una cuenta de google (utilizaremos google meet). Se recomienda tener conocimientos básicos de R.

¡ATENCIÓN! por cuestiones de seguridad virtual, el enlace a la reunión se enviará unos minutos antes de la misma. Por ello les pedimos que
estén alertas al correo.

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: What's New and Upcoming with tidymodels  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
Max Kuhn returns again to tell us about new happenings in tidymodels.

This meetup is the runup to the 2021 Government & Public Sector R Conference and Workshops taking place virtually December 8-10. Members of the group can use code nyhackr for a 20% discount at https://rstats.ai/gov/.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack: https://nyhackr.org/slack.html

About the Talk:
The tidymodels framework is a collection of packages for modeling and machine learning using tidyverse principles. We've been working hard to add new features and fix bugs. I'll talk about censored regression, model deployment, case weights, and other features in progress. Additionally, the results from this year's user poll will be shown.

About Max:
Max Kuhn is a software engineer at RStudio. He is currently working on improving R's modeling capabilities. He was a Senior Director of Nonclinical Statistics at Pfizer Global R&D in Connecticut. He was applying models in the pharmaceutical and diagnostic industries for over 18 years. Max has a Ph.D. in Biostatistics. Max is the author of numerous R packages for techniques in machine learning and reproducible research. He, and Kjell Johnson, wrote the book Applied Predictive Modeling, which won the Ziegel award from the American Statistical Association, which recognizes the best book reviewed in Technometrics in 2015. Their second book, Feature Engineering and Selection, was published in 2019.

The talk will begin at 7 PM America/New_York and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

title: Vienna<-R: Tunis-R / ViennaR: Tidy Network Data Using {tidygraph} in R  [Virtual] , Austria, Europe
description:
Announcing the fourth meetup of the OnePackagePerMeetup series that was recently started at Tunis R User Group.

TunisR will be hosting Thomas Lin Pedersen who will walk through the "tidygraph" R-package (https://www.data-imaginist.com/2017/introducing-tidygraph/). Thomas Lin Pedersen is a software engineer at RStudio focusing on developing and maintaining the various packages that makes data visualisation possible in R. He is the maintainer of ggplot2 and the developer of a range of extensions such as patchwork, ggforce, and gganimate. In the spare time, Thomas makes generative art created with R using the same tools as he develops for data visualisation.

➡️ Place: Zoom
➡️ Date/Time: December 2, 2021 from 7PM to 9PM Tunisian time (UTC +1)

Have a look at the convenient world clock website https://lnkd.in/gUAZxQM if you're struggling to find the right time according to your time zone.

➡️ About the workshop:
Working with network data can be daunting for people used to the more classic tabular data types. The packages tidygraph and ggraph have been developed to bring some of the familiarity of dplyr and ggplot2 to working with network data with the hope that more people will be comfortable wrangling and analysing this type of data. This workshop will introduce the core concepts of network data and show how it can be tamed with the help of tidygraph and ggraph.

title: R-Ladies Philly: Building Packages at Work  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
This holiday season, consider treating your coworkers (and yourself!) to an R package - the gift that keeps on giving!

A series of short presentations on the topic of R package development and maintenance in the workplace. When is a package the right solution. What can be put into a package. And how to make a package built to last.

Speakers: Alison Moss, Jake Riley, and Jess Streeter

More details coming soon.

Presentations:

1)
Alison Moss presents: dataVisEasy - seamless integration of metadata and data for easy and accurate visualizations

After getting tired of running similar lines of code over and over again to make minor adjustments to heatmaps and data visualizations, I accidentally found myself writing several functions to make all that tweaking easier, eventually turning into it into a package. Now seamlessly integrating metadata into data visualizations is nice and easy and all those minor tweaks your boss asks for don’t have to be an extra source of stress.

Alison just recently graduated with her PhD from Thomas Jefferson University and is now working at Rajant Health Inc as a Computational Biologist. She absolutely loves coding in R and gets way too much enjoyment out of writing and debugging functions to make data analysis and visualizations easy and consistent.

2)
Jess Streeter presents: Nerdify your life

Learn about Spring Health's internal package, Nerdify, and how it has streamlined several internal processes across our growing data team.

Jess is a Senior Data Scientist at Spring Health. She has spent her entire career working on issues around mental health. When she's not coding away, she enjoys spending time with her family, drinking good beer, and training Jiu Jitsu.

Please note: We are limited to 100 attendees, so make sure to join on time if you'd like to participate in the live event. The workshop will be recorded and shared on our YouTube channel shortly after the meetup event.

title: R-Ladies Goiânia: Análise de Dados com Redes em R  [Virtual] , Brazil, Latin America
description:
Heey, tudo bem?

Estamos muito felizes com a sua participação.

Aproveite o curso. Aproveite essa oportunidade! Este evento foi pensado com muito carinho para você.

O que você vai aprender?

O curso Análise de Dados com Redes em R busca transmitir conhecimentos teórico-práticos sobre as etapas que envolvem a inferência e interpretação de redes a partir de dados heterogêneos na área de saúde, o que engloba desde dados biomoleculares até dados clínicos. A parte teórica envolverá medidas de correlação e dependência estatística, algoritmos de inferência de rede e avaliação de modelos gráficos. A parte prática se dará através de pacotes da linguagem de programação R exemplificando várias técnicas de inferência de redes.

Quais pacotes vão ser utilizados ?

library(igraph)

Sobre o Projeto Enigma

O projeto Enigma busca tornar visível o papel feminino na área da computação, resgatando as contribuições significativas de algumas mulheres de uma forma diferenciada, que provoque o pensamento do fruidor. Não pretende-se reproduzir as visibilidades que estas personagens já têm, mas fazer uma provocação, desacomodando o pensamento para que as invisibilidades, que ainda persistem, se tornem visíveis. As doações serão voltadas a reforma de artigos doados ao projeto como computadores, teclados e entre outros objetos do universo computacional.

Para saber mais sobre este projeto lindo acesse https://www.ufrgs.br/enigma/

E aí? Topa?

Link de inscrição: https://www.sympla.com.br/produtor/cursosonline

Dúvidas frequentes:

CERTIFICADOS! - O certificado de 4h do evento será enviado para o seu e-mail. Caso você não receba ao final do evento, escreva para [masked].

MATERIAIS! - Os materiais utilizados no nosso curso (apresentação, scripts) serão disponibilizados através do nosso GitHub .

Dicas importantes para melhor aproveitamento do evento

(1°) Procure conectar o seu computador no cabo de rede, evitando instabilidades na transmissão;
(2°) Pré-configure a sua câmera e microfone antes de entrar no evento pois será útil para as interações com a professora em caso de dúvidas!
(3°) Prepare seu ambiente, aquela caneca de café, garrafa de água e os fones de ouvido, melhores companheiros para se concentrar e mergulhar de cabeça nessa experiência!
(4°) Não guarde esse conhecimento apenas para você, compartilhe com seus amigos e redes sociais marcando a gente no instagram @rladiesgyn.

Você faz parte desse compromisso

Lembre-se que o Código de Conduta também se estende à versão online de nossos eventos e não será tolerada qualquer forma de assédios ou intimidações de qualquer participante, seja audiência, palestrantes, colaboradores, ou quaisquer membros da comunidade.

A gente brilha TOGETHER!

title: trigeR - Trójmiejska Grupa Entuzjastów R: WhyR? Webinar: Recent developments of Joint Models using R  [Virtual] , Poland, Europe
description:
WhyR? Webinars are back !

Webinar: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eC1-B2RLGwk

Title:
Recent developments of Joint Models for longitudinal and survival data using R

Abstract:

Many biomedical follow-up studies aim to investigate the relationship between a repeated measurement, measured with error and time-to-event data. Joint modelling approaches are used to study these two types of data simultaneously to assess the effect of longitudinal biomarkers on time-to-event data. The first joint modelling proposals have been based on a relationship between one single longitudinal biomarker and time-to-event data. Recently, several extensions have been developed for multivariate longitudinal and survival data, for non-linear longitudinal and survival data, to use different association structures between the longitudinal biomarker and patients` survival and for personalized dynamic predictions of time-to-event data. In this talk, we will focus on the recent developments of joint models from both frequentist and Bayesian perspective, with developed R packages.

Speaker: Ipek Guler

I am Ipek Guler born in Turkey in 1986, after finishing my University degree in Gazi University, Ankara, I have started to my master degree in University of Santiago de Compostela, Spain where I have specialized in applied statistical techniques. During my master studies, I had different internships in Clinical Hospital of Santiago de Compostela, IDICHUS and a spin-off company and I focused my research on longitudinal and survival data.

I have worked in several research projects as a researcher in biostatistics group of University of Santiago de Compostela during 6 years, as a statistical consultant in Maimonides Biomedical Research Institute of Córdoba (IMIBIC) for 2 years and also have worked in national Covid registry data with the Spanish Internal Medicine Society (SEMI). I am currently working in Leuven Biostatistics and Statistical Bioinformatics Centre (L-BioStat) KU Leuven.

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: Level up your ggplot: How do I add labels, arrows and other annotations?  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
In this workshop, we'll discuss different ways of annotating your plots. For example, we might want to highlight data points that defy the overall trend, or explain what a line or colour within the graph means, or comment on and interpret the plot.
We'll first show you how to manually draw arrows and insert text boxes in your graph. Then, we'll explore the annotation geoms the {ggforce} package offers and recreate the commented Bechdel test graph you can see at the top of the page.

---
It's important to us to ensure that R-Ladies Freiburg events are a safe space for gender minorities and especially those who are just starting out with R. All are welcome at this meetup but we specifically ask cisgender men to take a passive role in this meetup and hold comments/ questions until after others have had the chance to ask. Thank you for your support!

title: R-Ladies Barcelona: Model tasting with Tidymodels  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:

We are back in December with a virtual talk/workshop called "Model tasting with Tidymodels" by Maria Dermit, on Thursday 2nd of December at 18:30!
You can install the tidymodels framework packages before the event (install.packages("tidymodels"))

Note that you will receive the password to connect to the event approximately one hour before the session starts.

--------

About the speaker:

Maria is a computational biologist at Bitbio (Cambridge, UK). She is a former postdoctoral research scientist in biomedicine at Queen Mary University of London. She uses data science to extract valuable information from big datasets produced in the laboratory, with the aim to advance cancer research. Starting from a biochemistry and bioinformatics background, Maria became passionate about mentoring, promoting the power of R, and using it in creative ways to connect with others.

title: R-Ladies Baltimore: R-Ladies Baltimore -- Panel Discussion on Careers in Data Science (Virtual)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is the local Baltimore chapter for the larger R-Ladies global organization (rladies.org) to promote gender diversity in the R community.

The next event is Monday November 29, 2021 from 7-8pm ET (virtual meetup on Zoom). We will have a set of brilliant panelists who will talk about careers in data science:

- Stefanie Nickels (https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=zi1f0qUAAAAJ&hl=en), Data Scientist at Verily Life Sciences

title: BernR: An Introduction to R with the Stanford Heart Transplant data  [Virtual] , Switzerland, Europe
description:
A presentation by Simon Schwab from Swisstransplant, Bern.

The event takes place online. The link to the meeting will be visible for registered participants shortly before the beginning of the event (at the latest).

This is the first session of a new introductory series into R for beginners called "R Fundamentals". This first session gives a brief overview of R and RStudio:
- data types
- exploring data
- some basic statistics
- figures with ggplot2
- R Notebooks

Examples will be from Stanford Heart Transplant dataset from the "survival" package. Slides and materials (R notebook) will be made available before the session at https://osf.io/ex6v7/. Thus, if desired, the audience can interact with the data already during the session.

Future R Fundamentals will cover specific topics in more detail, e.g. data reading & data cleaning, ggplot2, descriptive statistics, etc.

title: R-Ladies Santa Barbara: R-Ladies SB x Central Coast Python: Data Science with R & Python, United States, US/Canada
description:
Mark you calendars for a first-of-its-kind R-Ladies SB x Central Coast Python Meetup on December 15th!

Python can be a powerful alternative/complementary language to R, and while we here at R-Ladies are certainly partial to the latter, adding another language to our data science toolkit is something we are always excited for.

We have collaborated with Central Coast Python to bring you an R to Python (and vice versa) translation workshop, where we will learn to wrangle and visualize the same dataset using both languages.

This event is open to R/Python enthusiasts of all skill levels!

You may choose to follow along on our screens or download the required software and packages to code along on your own machines. If you do not already have R and Python installed, please be sure to do so before the event on December 15th. Find our installation instructions for R/RStudio, Python/Anaconda, and required packages on the event's GitHub README: https://github.com/samanthacsik/RLadiesSB-RvsPython

We will be available to help troubleshoot any setup issues on 12/07 from 5:30-6:30pm via Zoom: https://ucsb.zoom.us/j/81620992244?pwd=d2ZQTCtwZVZvU3Q4M25FN1hIM1Fxdz09.

This will be a hybrid in-person/remote event. We are excited to begin meeting/networking with our communities once again, but understand that not everyone may be comfortable attending events in person still. We will do our best to answer questions for those attending virtually, but please understand that we may be slow to respond as we navigate our first hybrid event.

PLEASE NOTE: Masks are required for in-person attendance and vaccination status will be verified at the door.

DIRECTIONS: This event will be held at the National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis (NCEAS) at 1021 Anacapa St. Our offices conveniently sit at SB city lot #8. The first 75min of parking are free and $1.50 per hour after that. Street parking is also available on the surrounding streets. Please enter the first floor office space through the side door that faces the parking lot (located on the left side of the building, if your back is to Anacapa St.).

REMOTE ATTENDEES: Please join the event via Zoom https://ucsb.zoom.us/j/82671745133

Banner Image Source: https://towardsdatascience.com/is-python-faster-than-r-db06c5be5ce8

title: Moffitt Cancer Center Bio-Data Club: Third Annual Bio-Data Club Hackathon  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Registration for the Bio-Data Club's Third Annual Hackathon is now open! You can register using this form: https://forms.gle/2ejXxdk4q8oT6XkJ6 . The hackathon will commence virtually on Thursday December 9th 2021 at 9am and conclude with virtual project presentations on December 10th at 3pm. The hackathon GitHub page (https://github.com/pstew/biodataclub/tree/master/meetings/2021-12_hackathon) has more information including descriptions of the projects and the tentative schedule. The list of projects for this year’s hackathon can be found here: https://github.com/pstew/biodataclub/blob/master/meetings/2021-12_hackathon/Project_descriptions.md .

A hackathon is an event in which participants come together to build a software product during a short period of time. Here is a short article describing what you can expect: https://www.rasmussen.edu/degrees/technology/blog/what-is-a-hackathon/. Last year’s hackathon (https://github.com/pstew/biodataclub/tree/master/meetings/2020-12_hackathon) featured 55 participants working collaboratively on 7 projects. Like last year, projects featured in this year's hackathon all have potential benefits for Moffitt.

This will be a fun event and we encourage everyone to sign up! The event will be very low stakes, and we encourage friendly competition between teams. Some programming background in any language is recommended but not required. If you are not confident in your programming skills, then there may be non-programming tasks such as finding validation datasets, cleaning data, creating figures, or creating slides for the results presentation that will still allow you to participate.

Please register by Monday, December 6th at 12pm or you may not be able to participate. We look forward to seeing you there!

The Bio-Data Club 2021 Hackathon Organizing Committee
(Anders Berglund, Rodrigo Carvajal, Jordan Creed, Guillermo Gonzalez-Calderon, Jose Laborde, Richie Reich, Paul Stewart)
